title: Thangka
summary: A thangka is a traditional Tibetan Buddhist painting, typically on cotton or silk appliqué, depicting Buddhist deities, scenes, or mandalas. These unframed scrolls are mounted on a textile backing with a silk cover, designed to be rolled up when not on display. Thangkas vary in size, from small pieces for personal meditation or monastic instruction to very large ones displayed during religious festivals. They serve as crucial teaching tools, illustrating the life of Buddha, influential lamas, and bodhisattvas, including concepts like the Wheel of Life. Their delicate nature requires dry storage to preserve the silk. Historically, Tibetan Buddhist painting evolved from earlier widespread Buddhist art traditions found in places like Ajanta and Mogao Caves. Today, printed reproductions are common for devotional and decorative use.

current_status: Printed reproductions of thangkas are commonly used today for devotional and decorative purposes. Original thangkas continue to be revered and used for traditional purposes like meditation and instruction. Their delicate nature necessitates careful preservation, with originals typically stored rolled and unframed in dry conditions.
future_prospects: The continued relevance of thangkas is likely in devotional and instructional contexts. Digital preservation and accessibility of thangka imagery could expand their reach. Ongoing efforts to preserve traditional thangka painting techniques and existing ancient pieces are expected.
